name: lila
comment info:
In the time series graph, it displays Serena Williams’s world ranking in tennis since 1998. It highlights the times when she was No. 1 in the sport in addition to how long she held the spot. It also shows when her ranking dropped. The infographic chart shows Grand Slam tournaments from 1998-2022 and whether or not Serena Williams participated or won. 
 
 
In the time series graph, I notice that the height of Serena Williams’s career was from February 2013 to September 2016 as she remained at the No. 1 world ranking for 186 weeks. Additionally, 2006 and 2017 were her worst years as she lost popularity and her international ranking temporarily. In the infographic chart, I notice that she played in the majority of Grand Slam tournaments that have taken place since 1998. However, she only won 23 while she participated in 80. 
 
I wonder why her popularity fell in 2006 as brought out by the time series graph. I’m also curious as to how she was able to maintain 3 ½ years as the No. 1 spot from 2013-2016. In regards to the infographic chart, I wonder why she failed to play in 20 tournaments. 
 
A headline for graph 1 could be The Popularity of Serena Williams. For graph 2, Grand Slam Games Played by Serena Williams.

name: Sean
comment info:
Having analysed the graph, Serena Williams' improvement is clearly displayed by the positive correlation of the scatter plot. As her career progressed, she continued to defeat opponents at every level, including those with up to 10 more years of experience in tennis. 

I wonder what caused to lose to opponents younger than her in the prime of her career. Was she battling mental struggles? Other renowned female athletes such as Liz Cambage, and Simone Biles have also been in the same position. Moreover, if this was the case, what led her to overcome those changes in her mindset?

As an athlete myself, I ask this question to hopefully apply it to my life and learn from one of the best athletes of all time.

Ultimately, this graph demonstrates a positive correlation of Serena Williams' wins (blue data points) as her career advanced asserting herself as the best female tennis player of all time.

name: Josiah
comment info:
I notice that the vast majority of Serena's games were played while she was older than her opponent. I also notice that she has more wins that losses, and despite that fact she lost both her first and last match ever. Finally, I notice that she only ever had one massively outlier game where she was younger than her opponent by 10+ years despite being 31.

I wonder how Serena kept motivating herself to continue playing even after all her success, lifelong fame and wear and tear on her badge. I wonder how many other players have managed to get to her age range while still playing professionally, and additionally how many managed to maintain their play level while aging like Serena did. 

While she didn't influence me personally, I can see how she impacted the lives of members of my community, the black community. Serena Williams influenced young black people and girls in general to push and work hard for the careers they dreamed of, opened up paths for black people to try for career fields that weren't typically for black people, and pushed black people and women into trying for professional tennis careers that they otherwise wouldn't have even thought about.

A good way to summarize this graphs contents is to say that it is displaying the wins and losses of Serena Williams' career while also comparing the age of both her and her opponent in those matches. name: Amanda Giuliani
comment info:
From my class:

We notice that at the beginning, her championship matches were a year apart and then they became more frequent.  There were more championship matches when she was 30-35yo and less from 35-40yo.  We wonder what was her overall win/loss record?  Who were her first and last opponents?  What happened when she was 29 and 36 (no data)?  Are there more older athletes still performing at a high level today (i.e. Tom Brady, LeBron James), or are they more celebrated now?  For impact, we wonder how engineers are adapting.  Do they need to design products differently with older athletes in mind?  We also talked about recovery processes.  Do we have better recovery processes and procedures already available to extend the life of the athlete, or is this something we need to continue developing?  Our headline:  "No matter the age, Serena is best."

replies.comment info: @Amanda Giuliani This is an amazing display of information based on one graph. It brings me joy your class could get so much from this.

name: Moderator Corey
comment info:
What a response on the Serena graph! Your responses came from across the country and several countries, with the most from Mexico. Thanks to the over 600 students who responded.

Two schools had a slew of great headlines, so we’d like to give a shout out to many of them. From Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey, shout outs for “Serena Williams Serves Greatness Despite Age Gap” by Ashley, “Serena's Domination: Age Is Just a Number” by Samuel, “Never Letting Age Stop Her, Serena Williams's Track Record" by Sebastian and "Serena Williams SLAMS Through Competition Despite Age" by Noah.  From Andover, Massachusetts, shout outs for “Serena Williams: Dominant No Matter The Age” by May and “Age Was No Barrier: Serena’s Success Story” by Wyatt. And, finally, “Serena Willams still catching dubs at the age of 40” by Isaac from Great Neck North.

You can continue to post responses. Please check back by Friday, Sept.16 to see the Reveal with the free link to the original New York Times article plus a link to more Serena graphs, some questions about the graph, and a few Stat Nuggets.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who was astounded by Serena’s power, concentration and style in last week’s U.S. Open, and Corey Andreasen of The Hague Netherlands, who is amazed by the number of barriers Serena has smashed, as well as the number of opponents of all ages.
